name: Celtic Twilight
sources: Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: An early 20th-century Irish artistic movement, known as the Celtic Twilight, was mostly literary with the participation of artists, politicians, and other visionaries. These individuals saw themselves living in a long dim evening after a glorious ancient "day" of Celtic heroism and romance. Poets of the time, like William Butler Yeats, wrote poems using the personae of ancient divinities or telling their myths. Dramatists, such as Lady Augusta Gregory, set their works in a reconstructed Celtic Ireland. Although some artworks from this period seem self-conscious or contrived when compared to early modernist art, the Celtic Twilight ideals resulted in the preservation of a significant amount of folklore and oral literature, which may have been lost otherwise. The movement also emphasized the then-dying Irish language, which partially led to its revival as the national language of the new Republic and the insistence on teaching it in schools. This ensured the maintenance of the language during a critical time. The center of this movement was in Míde.
